title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state that there will be a surplus at a wage of $192, calculate the surplus as 80 leather workers, and/or does not show the work.

Surplus=Quantity Supplied−Quantity Demanded=400−320=80 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6938@

The response states that there will be a surplus at a wage of $192, calculates the surplus as 80 leather workers, and shows the work.

Surplus=Quantity Supplied−Quantity Demanded=400−320=80 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6938@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing number of workers as 240 and/or does not explain that at that quantity, the marginal revenue product is equal to the marginal factor cost.
The response identifies the profit-maximizing number of workers as 240 and explains that at that quantity, the marginal revenue product is equal to the marginal factor cost.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the wage the firm will pay as $128 and/or does not explain that this is the wage on the supply curve at the profit-maximizing number of workers (where marginal revenue product is equal to marginal factor cost).

The response identifies the wage the firm will pay as $128 and explains that this is the wage on the supply curve at the profit-maximizing number of workers (where marginal revenue product is equal to marginal factor cost).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the perfectly competitive wage would be $176 and/or does not explain that the wage would be determined by the intersection of the supply curve and the marginal revenue product curve.
The response states that the perfectly competitive wage would be $176 and explains that the wage would be determined by the intersection of the supply curve and the marginal revenue product curve.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state that the firm should hire fewer leather workers and/or does not explain that the ratio of the marginal product of labor to the wage (3) is less than the ratio of the marginal product of capital to the rental price of capital (8), or the firm can get more output for their money by hiring fewer workers, or
